title: Tuesday, 21st June, 2016

11:04 am
PM

We provide a scenario framework to consider the potential investment implications of a UK vote to Remain or to Leave. Financials, Telcos, Consumer Cyclicals and the periphery should gain most under Remain. Consumer Staples, Healthcare, Energy and weaker FX beneficiaries to outperform under Leave.

PM

Introducing scenario analysis for Remain or Leave.
Ahead of Thursday's referendum, we lay out a framework to provide some context around market performance in the event of a vote to Remain or Leave. Given the high level of uncertainty involved, we introduce a scenario analysis around both outcomes.

PM

REMAIN framework suggests 6-11% rally in our base case...
We expect a 6-11% rally in our 'base case' Remain scenario as European equities recover recent underperformance but fail to push on further. SX5E rallies up to 3150-3300 and FTSE100 rises to 6500-6800. A more bullish scenario would likely depend on the margin of a Remain outcome pace of renewed inflows, lingering UK political risks and scope for a rebound in growth indicators.
… led by Financials, Telecoms, Consumer cyclicals and Periphery.
The best short-term performance under a Remain is likely to come from Banks, Insurance, Diversified Financials, Telecoms, Media and Retailing. Our peripheral exposure basket (MSSTPERI) should also outperform. Consumer Staples, Healthcare and Energy are likely to be relative underperformers.
LEAVE framework suggests 13-18% drop in our base case...
We believe markets could fall by up to 13-18% in our 'base case' Leave scenario, led initially by a drop in Europe's N12M PE back to its long-run median. SX5E drops down to 2400-2550 and FTSE100 falls to 5000-5300. Bull and bear scenarios depend on policymakers' responses, political newsflow in UK and Eurozone and FX volatility.
…with Staples, Healthcare, Energy and weaker FX beneficiaries outperforming.
Financials, Consumer Cyclicals and the periphery are likely to lead markets lower initially post a Leave outcome. Consumer Staples, Healthcare, Energy and weaker EUR/GBP beneficiaries are likely to be relative outperformers. The UK is likely to modestly outperform Europe.

n 4 for 9 rights issue at a price of 94 pence

BE

Barclays incoming.

BE

Interim results below our low expectations and guidance for the full year reduced “FY16 full year anticipated to be slightly below market expectations” (company compiled consensus is for FY16 underlying operating profit of £48.7m (Barclays £49.4m). This still demands significant H2 weighting, as only £3.8m of operating profit was delivered in H1. Order book cover is c. 90% (c. £240m) of expected H2 revenue, including the delayed £103m 40mm contract which is now in production, meaning that this is more a question of delivery than hope. Even so, we note that revenue misses towards the end of the fiscal year have typically ‘dropped through’ at a c. 50% margin. Recent precedent does not provide much comfort, with warnings in four of the last five years towards the end of the fiscal year when much was expected in H2.

11:22 am
BE

The lower than expected performance is despite sales +11.4% YoY, with increases in all three divisions. This is due to the later than anticipated commencement of the 40mm ammunition contract, lower margin sales mix, phasing of revenue within FY16E and contract specific issues resolved in H1.

Order book of £591.3m, which compares with £593.8m at the end of January and £569.6m at the end of October. We have noted previously that if we assume just over 50% of the order book is US dollar denominated then the growth in the order book since October could all be accounted for by the weakening of sterling relative to the US dollar (figures in the FY15 report & accounts detailing the impact of a 10 cent movement in the US$/£ exchange rate suggest that c. 51% of sales in FY15 were US dollar denominated, although we believe this figure has a reasonable degree of variability year to year and it is also unclear whether this calculation includes the impact of US$ proxy currencies).

BE

Net debt £114.4m (2.0x LTM debt vs 3.0x covenant), which is marginally better than our £117.2m estimate. The slightly better outturn despite much lower than anticipated profitability in H1 appears to be largely due to a working capital outflow of £6.2m versus our £20m outflow.

Chemring is currently trading on a PER of 12.6x, falling to 11.0x the Bloomberg consensus for FY16E and FY17E respectively. This compares with the current UK A&D average of 13.1x on a 12mth forward basis. Chemring has historically (5yr average) traded at an 11% discount to the sector average. The shares are also trading on an EV/sales of 1.2x and EV/EBITA of 10.1x our current published FY17E estimates.

BE

And JPM Caz.

11:23 am
BE

What happened in H1 16? There were two main reasons, and some
smaller reasons, why EBITA was below CHG’s plan. (1) The important
contract from a M.East customer for 40mm ammunition was secured in
April 2016 but this was later than expected and only allowed for one month
of shipments in H1 16. This contract will last more than 2 years and make a 6-month
contribution in H2 16 (c£30m of revenues). (2) In Countermeasures, there
were execution issues in Australia (which forced one facility to stop
production for two months) and in the UK; we estimate these hit EBITA by
c£2m in H1 16. (3) There were sundry other issues in Countermeasures,
including a small execution issue in the US and weaker volumes in
Australia (in addition to the execution issue just mentioned).

BE

Can CHG achieve our new FY16 estimate? Having delivered EBITA of
£3.8m in H1 16, CHG would need to deliver £41.9m in H2 16 to meet our
new FY16 estimate. This compares to £28.9m in H2 15. CHG points out
that it entered H2 16 with 90% of expected H2 16 revenues already in its
order book, with the remaining 10% to come from multiple small contracts
that it is confident of securing. This differs to the start of H2 15, when CHG
only had 75% of expected H2 15 revenues in its order book, and the
remaining 25% was largely dependent on one large M.East contract. Whilst
this explanation should offer some comfort, investors may be somewhat
nervous that CHG may not meet our revised FY16 EPS and FCF estimates.

BE

Investec stay buyers, FWIW.

11:24 am
BE

Trading: Revenue of £180.1m, was up 11% y-o-y, but EBITA was down £1.7m at £3.8m. Net debt at £114.4m is expected to reduce significantly through H2 as the H1 working capital build unwinds (mainly inventory). In H1 £48.8m of loan notes were repaid using the proceeds of the rights issue. As expected, no interim dividend has been declared.
Divisional outturn: Countermeasures was loss making (-£1.4m, down £6.1m y-o-y) while Sensors & Electronics (at £5.7m, up £4.8m) showed a marked improvement. Energetics Systems saw revenue progress, but EBITA was down from £3.6m to £3.0m. £6.4m of the 40mm contract was delivered with a greater amount expected in H216.
Outlook: With c.90% of H2 revenues covered by the £591m order book, this represents a better position than a year ago. The requirement for less order intake during H2 (than last year) should partially reassure and the focus will be on whether the company can deliver the order book on time and without operational issues. We still assume a c.80% H2 profit weighting. The longer term outlook is unchanged with expected progress made on the all-important US Programs of Record. These programs offer material revenues over the next decade and Chemring is well placed to be the primary provider. This combined with operational changes (including site closures) should see good profit progression from FY17E, a view which is unchanged despite the setback today.

11:33 am
BE

JUST EAT has just announced that it has appointed Paul Harrison as its
new Chief Financial Officer and Executive Director with effect from
September 26th 2016, replacing Mike Wroe who will be standing down as
Chief Financial Officer as at that date. Mr Wroe will stay with the business
until the end of 2016 and also remain available through H1 17. While this
step may come as a surprise to the market, we believe the long transition
phase over the next couple of months should ensure a smooth succession.
In addition, we think the company’s recent Investor Day highlighted the
strength not only of the CEO and CFO, but also of other senior
management.

BE

We are Overweight the stock: We are OW, and see upside potential to
our base case assumptions, which offer 2015-18E CAGRs of +32% for
revenue and +55% for EBITDA, together with high cash conversion. We
see further potential upside to numbers from better-than-expected order
volumes (as H1 15, Q3 15, FY 15 and Q1 16 results have all
demonstrated), additional M&A, the Brazilian JV, move into pick-up /
collection, and faster-than-expected increases in commission rates. On
our estimates, the stock trades on 16/17 EV/EBITDA of 27.7x/16.9x and
a 2.9%/4.6% Eq FCF yield.

BE

I then got lost in JPM's previous research drawing parallels between classified ad spend in UK autos and takeaway advertising, but it's not really something I can share usefully.

11:35 am
BE

Instead, here's Jefferies. (Also very positive.)

BE

Wroe, a corporate architect at work. Wroe joined Just Eat in 2008 I think, I first met him in 2011, a small, cramped office in central London as I recall. An archetypal 'growth' CFO, Mike essentially built the Finance and supporting operational teams from the ground up, completing two VC funding rounds along the way and helping to drive international expansion at the Just Eat Group, much of that via M&A.

Heavily involved in 2014's IPO, Just Eat listed at 260p, closing last night at 450p. In Just Eat's short history as a public company, the financial prints have been positive, without exception, and the Street has been managed effectively and with a degree of aplomb.

Perhaps best covered off by CEO Buttress's words in today's press release 'I would like to thank Mike for the outstanding job he has done as CFO of Just Eat since 2008. In that time, Just Eat has grown from a small private company with a big vision, to a large public business with even greater ambitions. He has been a trusted colleague and friend throughout, expertly marshalling Just Eat through our IPO and our very strong performance since. I wish him all the best for the future.'

The recent Just Eat CMD. Two key messages from the event on the 10 June were;

The overarching message, a strong bench. Just Eat hosted a well attended Capital Markets Day on Friday 10 June at its London Head Office. One key objective to showcase the quality of the Just Eat management team, job done, some very impressive presentations delivered on the day; and
Actively managed by CEO Buttress. CEO David Buttress drives growth hard at Just Eat, unafraid to make the tough decisions, Buttress has replaced both the long standing CMO, Mat Braddy and the equally well established CTO, Carlos Morgado.The replacements Barnaby Dawe and Fernando Fanton both on show at the CMD and clearly both very well suited to taking Just Eat through the next stage of growth.

BE

New CFO, Paul Harrison. More proactive management at work here, Harrison well suited to helping Just Eat develop further as a listed company. The 13 years at Sage would be characterised as the archetypal 'safe pair of hands'...I have never covered WANdisco, but imagine that to be a slightly different learning experience from Sage. Harrison also holds non-executive roles at Hays and Ascential.

And worth mentioning Marcus Jennings, Group Finance Director. The management bench is strong at Just Eat, part and parcel of Buttress's strategy. Jennings, I believe is a real asset, a polished Finance professional, having been with Just Eat since 2011. The continuity he brings is a positive and beneath the hood, one would expect Jennings to continue to manage a very effective Just Eat Finance function.

In conclusion... Change always brings risk, but CEO Buttress has hired well in the past. One assumes the character fit is a good one, and it is a given that Harrison brings the right skill set for the Just Eat CFO at this stage of the company's development. Not close enough to WANdisco to fully understand if that will raise eyebrows, it has been a volatile equity. Wroe a tough act to follow in my opinion, but the timing feels right.

BE

11:45 am
BE

This morning SNR published an unexpected trading update for H1 2016,
warning that EBITA would be lower than expected in Flexonics, its
industrial business. We cut our 2016-18E EPS 8%/10%/10%. This is the
fifth material reduction in our estimates since we assumed coverage of
SNR (from our SMID cap team) in June 2015. We remain positively
inclined to SNR’s civil aero business but clearly under-estimated the risks
in the industrial segment. We reduce our multiples-based Dec-16 price
target by 11% to 240p, reflecting our lower EPS estimates. We downgrade
to Neutral from OW.

BE

And Investec.

BE

The FY16 outturn at Flexonics will be worse than the c.25% y/y decline in EBIT we had forecast, reflecting continued weakness in truck, off highway and oil & gas markets. We estimate that updated guidance for the group implies a c.12% cut to consensus PBT. Senior has demonstrated it can successfully navigate weak end markets in the past, although investors will likely factor in a margin for further downside risk, in our view. We place our forecasts, rating and target price under review.

Details: Senior has issued a pre-close statement and updated FY16 guidance. The company expects the Flexonics H1 margin to be in the 8-9% range due to weakness in truck, off highway and Oil & Gas markets. Flexonics revenues in H2 could be lower than H1, although Senior expects an improvement in margins in H2 due to cost-cutting measures.
In Aerospace, Senior expects y-o-y revenue growth in H1 but margins will be lower. We had already forecast this. The company expects growth in Aerospace in FY16, but EBIT to be weighted to H2 as the division benefits from increasing revenues and operational improvements.
Changes to consensus forecasts: We expect a c.£8m-9m cut to consensus forecasts for FY16 Flexonics EBIT, and a c.£1-2m cut to Aerospace EBIT. This should lead to a c.£10m or c.10-12% cut to FY16 consensus PBT (£94m according to Bloomberg) and a larger cut to consensus EPS forecasts.
Cash: Senior has not commented on cash, but we had already expected FCF conversion to remain weak in FY16E due to increased investments and working capital build and to begin to improve from FY17E, driven by lower investment in Aerospace and a recovery in Flexonics end markets.

11:46 am
BE

In terms of the readthrough, we're looking at JMAT.

Johnson Matthey PLC (JMAT:LSE): Last: 2,940, up 7 (+0.24%), High: 2,949, Low: 2,910, Volume: 139.28k
BE

And thanks to Liberum's Adam Collins, who's sent over a note talking in doom-y terms about the North American truck market.

11:47 am
BE

.... Class 8 (Heavy) North American truck orders were over 40% lower y-o-y in the 5 months to May, a significant demise which takes 3-6 months to feed through the value chain.... Senior's FD said on the analyst call today 'We still have a couple of weeks to go. But as it stands at the moment, we're seeing a reduction of roundabout 33% on the off-highway and truck revenue year-on-year for the first half'. .... Now it looks like it will be a similar amount in the second half.....''

BE

Senior's issues are worth noting for Johnson Matthey (Hold, TP£29.40) given that it generates a similar c10% of Group profits from trucks, weighted to the USA... At the FY15/16 Results meeting earlier this month JMAT's MD of ECT John Walker acknowledged US heavy duty truck is 'well over 50% of US HDD sales' but said he expected the 'Class 8 slowdown to impact revenues by around £25m and EBIT by low single digits' this year. We think US Class 8 revenues were around £240m in the year just ended or c60% of the £405m sales reported for HDD North America so the guidance of a £25m decline always looked low to us, equating to a c10% decline in the base.. That said JMAT has the benefit of c£26m restructuring related savings this year at the Group level so there are offsets..

BE

PM

BE

Detail -- not of the book, to be clear! The note -- is a bit dull. Recent underperformance, very little Brexit risk, yada yada.

BE

11:58 am
BE

We also have an upgrade through from Stifel on WH Smith, if anyone cares.

BE

Which usually sparks some debate on what on earth WH Smith's for.

BE

Yeah, we know. The travel business. 700 or so stores in captive locations selling giant Galaxy bars with copies of the Daily Telegraph.

12:00 pm
BE

But it also has 600 high street locations, empty apart from a week or two before Christmas when its customers buy their annual book.

BE

Whatever. Here's Stifel.

BE

We are upgrading our rating on WH Smith shares from Hold to Buy and setting a 1920p target price. The EU Referendum has increased short term uncertainty but management has plenty of experience in managing retail headwinds and change. The recent update shows that trading remains in line with expectations and the Travel growth/cash generation/shareholder returns strategy is intact. At a time of generally low interest rates, the shares' 5% effective dividend yield/5.6% FCF yield and medium term growth prospects look attractive to us.

12:00 pm
BE

Managing change: WHS senior management team (in place since 2004) has
weathered more challenging headwinds than a potential Brexit. Management's
intense focus on gross profit densities and cost efficiency has allowed the
group to grow profits and cash flow despite 1) the disappearance of
entertainment (CDs, DVDs, video games accounting for 25% of sales in 2004)
as a major High Street retail category and 2) the rise of Amazon, firstly in
books (still c.25% of WHS High Street sales) and subsequently across general
merchandise more broadly. We believe WH Smith management is well placed
to prosper irrespective of the Referendum outcome. The main risk to the group
would be a slowdown in passenger growth in UK airports and trains if UK
economic growth were impacted by Brexit.
Still trading in line: On June 8, the group issued a Q3 trading update that
was broadly in line with expectations. High Street LFL declined 3%, whereas
Travel LFLs increased 3% (total +9%). We expect further slight slowdowns in
LFLs in Q4 as comparisons toughen. Gross margins increased in both
divisions. We maintained our FY16 estimates at £131m PBT, 94.8p EPS
(FY17 £136m PBT, 101.0p EPS).
Cash generation, shareholder returns and growth define Buy case:
Excluding a one-off £13m HMRC contribution, we forecast current year Free
Cash Flow of £108m (FY17 £115m) and returns to shareholders of £97m
(dividends + buybacks). This equates to a 5.6% FCF yield or a c.5% dividend
yield (treating buybacks as income). The dividend is also forecast to grow at a
CAGR of 7% over the next four years.
Upgrade to Buy, 1920p TP: The shares have retreated around 12% from the
recent peak and we believe this represents a useful buying opportunity for
longer term, income-focused investors. Our 1920p target price is based on our
Discounted Cash Flow valuation. In our opinion, WH Smith shares deserve to
trade at a sector premium to reflect Travel division growth and strong group
free cash flow, the vast majority of which is returned to shareholders.

WH Smith PLC (SMWH:LSE): Last: 1,699, up 19 (+1.13%), High: 1,739, Low: 1,680, Volume: 207.66k
undefined
12:01 pm
PM

Look at the time

BE
